title: Exhibition charts Christian history in MidEast
description:
(29 Sep 2017) LEAD IN:
A new exhibition charting Christian history in the Middle East has opened in Paris.
"Eastern Christians – Two Thousand Years of History" includes 300 artworks and objects, some dating back as far as the third century.

STORY-LINE: 
Beautifully painted artwork adorns the walls of the Arab World Institute in Paris.
This religious iconography is part of a new exhibition tracing the dramatic history of Christians in the Middle East.
Around 300 pieces from Iraq, Syria, Jordan, Egypt and Lebanon are on display at "Eastern Christians – Two Thousand Years of History."  
Jack Lang, the President of the Arab World Institute, says the exhibition is a "world first" with the first such event dedicated to Christians from the region.
"Why there has never been any huge exhibition dedicated to a religion that is one of the components of the Arab World, and which played and is playing such an historical role? We wanted to address this shortcoming," he says.
There's a mosaic that once covered a church floor in Jordan, and vases and goblets used by Christians long ago.
But the oldest item here is a third century fresco of Jesus found in the ancient church of Dura Europas in eastern Syria.
Curator Raphaelle Ziade calls it the "most moving piece, if not the most important of the exhibition". 
"This is the first time those frescos have been in Europe. And this is the real beginning of Christian images, there are not any previous images. So this is the first time we see a representation of Christ," she says.
The exhibition spans the Antiquity period, medieval times, the Ottoman era and on to more contemporary works. 
Many items are on loan from some of the biggest museums in the world she including the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the British Museum and closer to home, the Louvre.
Monsignor Pascal Gollnisch directs the L'Oeuvre D'Orient, a Christian aid association that has assisted in putting this exhibition together. 
Gollnisch visited Mosul in July after it was liberated from the Islamic State group and his thoughts are with modern Christians from the region.
"If Iraq is going well, Christians from Iraq will be fine. If Iraq is taken to pieces, Christians will be facing threats and it will be bad," he says. 
"We cannot talk about the Christian minority as if it were a bubble living its pains, or its serenity, separately from the country."
The exhibition runs until 14 January 2018.
